lines.text:
[Introducing herself to Hester]
I'm Clarissa.
[Offering her Hesther piece of candy]
would you have a sugar violet?
No, thank you. I don't care for sugary things.

[after Hester bites him. Aroused with excitement]
I never thought I'd find a woman with a spirit as willful as mine. You take what you want and the devil with the consequences. So do I!
Who dishonors us, dies!

[to Peter]
All of us women are very much the same, you know.
[Gesturing toward a statue]
None of us should be put on pedestals.
You say you love her; well, so do I him; and if anyone comes between, so much the worse. I've no quarrel with those that don't interfere; but if you love her, keep her from getting in my way.
Pretty speech but dead in character. For once you've spoken the truth, my dear, I do believe you'd stop at nothing.
Then remember it!

There's one factor you've overlooked... me! You see, I'm not a gentleman. I swear but that if she comes to harm through you, I'd break that lovely little neck of yours with less regret than I'd stamp on a snake.
[He slaps her and departs]

[referring to Clarissa]
If she likes mud, let her sink in it!

[to Peter]
We've only had one month together. Not much in a lifetime.

[Referring to her unfinished portraiture]
You paint me as a happy mother. I'm not very happy. I'm scarcely a mother... and yet I smile because I'm supposed to be happy.
No, Lady Rohan; you smile because you're fortunate.
Aren't they the same thing?
A dairy maid can be happy; but she's not obliged to smile when she's wretched. The fortunate must pay their debt. A great lady must never been seen without a smile.

[Following Hesther's cold declination of Clarissa's offer of a sugar violet, Clarissa shivers]
Are you cold, Clarissa?
No; somebody walked over my grave.
